FROM THE GERMAN OF AUGUSTUS VON KOTZEBUE. WITH NOTES MARKING THE VARIATIONS FROM THE ORIGINAL.

NEW-YORK: PRINTED BY G. F. HOPKINS, FOR WILLIAM DUNLAP. AND SOLD AT THE OFFICE OF THE PRINTER, NO. 136 PEARL-STREET; T. AND J. SWORDS, NO. 99 PEARL-STREET; GAINE AND TEN-EYCK, NO. 148 PEARL-STREET; JOHN BLACK, NO. 5 CEDAR-STREET; ALEX. SOMERVILLE, NO. 114 MAIDEN-LANE; AND MOST OTHER BOOKSELLERS IN THE U. STATES. 1800.

div.head: PREFACE BY THE AUTHOR.
div.p: THIS piece is a continuation of my "Virgin of the Sun." My worthy friend, Mr. Schroeder, has made several slight alterations in it, upon which I, relying on his secrecyâ–ª might safely hold my peace; but which I shall now gratefully acknowledge; partly, because I am not ashamed to take instruction from such a man as Schroeder; partly, because otherwise some ill-tempered critic may, as heretofore, upon the applause which the piece receives, rush forward, like an envious blood-hound, to lessen my share of merit with the public. The alterations are such as Mr. Schroeder made himself, or such as I have made by his advice.

To the first of these belongs, in preference, the expunging a scene of Diego's, which, without having any connection with the interest of the whole, interrupted, by untimely jests, the progress of the first act. Further, the suppression of a finale, and an air which Elvira, very unseasonably, sung to the guitar. Further, the circumstance, that Pizarro only guessed at Elvira's design upon his life, which, before this alteration, Rolla, without hesitation, discovered to him; and thereby, perhaps, cast an appearance of ungenerous conduct upon his character. Further, the mitigating Pizarro's baseness, where he, in violation of his promise, seeks to get Rolla again in his power.

I have myself, at his desire, metamorphosed Valverde the priest, into a private secretary; because, wicked priests can be tolerated only on the great theatre of the world, and not upon the stage of a play-house. But I designed this alteration only for the stage; and, that the press should restore this wretch again to his historical character. At present I have neither time nor inclination to attend farther to him.
Unquestionably, the alteration which has been most serviceable to the piece is, the ennobling of Elvira's character, which I undertook by his advice, and for which I sincerely thank him.

Other alterations, which Mr. Schroeder thought proper to recommend, in compliance with the spirit of the times, I have not made. I see, for example, no reason why we should refrain
from saying, that the Pope, by his bull, made a present of America to the Spaniards; that, by another bull, he declared the Indians to be men and not apes; that thirteen Indians were crucified by the Spaniards to the honor of Christ and the twelve apostles. Why must that be suppressed on the stage, which history has so loudly proclaimed?

I take this opportunity of saying a few words concerning two other of my pieces. A certain Mr. Schutze has confidently asserted, in his History of the Hamburg Theatre, that Mr. Schroeder had made great alterations in "Count Benyowsky," to which that piece owed its success. This, with his permission, is not true. Mr. Schroeder altered nothing in "Count Benyowsky;" and Mr. Schutze will do well, in future, to seek better information.

The "Literary Gazette" has had the goodness to judge of my Sultan Wampum A very pleasant farce, which I hope to present to the public. TRANSLATOR. , (a hasty composition, upon which I do not set a very great value) with more kindness than I, perhaps, should have done myself; although it has formerly, in opposition to the public applause, condemned and trampled in the dust some performances of mine whose merit is far superior.

For this kindness I am grateful, and will here make known, that some of the censured, and truly censurable, verses do not belong to me, having been altered, probably to suit the fancy of the composer, without my knowledge; and remaining so, because I was too far from the place of publication to superintend the press.
German Theatre. No. III. PIZARRO IN PERU; OR, THE DEATH OF ROLLA.

div.head: PIZARRO IN PERU; OR, THE DEATH OF ROLLA.
SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: A magnificent pavilion near Pizarro's tentâ€”a view of the Spanish camp in the back ground.
ELVIRA is discovered sleeping under a canopy on one side of the pavilion.â€”VALVERDE enters, kneels and attempts to kiss the hand of ELVIRA; she rises and looks at him with indignation.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: FORGIVE the power of your charms.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Who has permitted thee to break in upon my slumbers? Is it not enough that the tumults of the camp destroy my nightly rest?â€”But leave me, and I forgive theeâ€”I would rather have my sense of hearing tortured, than my sight. Leave me, or I inform Pizarro of your insolence.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Inform Pizarro!â€”Nay, lady, rather inform me through what magic this Pizarro has enchained thee? Wild and unseemly in his looks, a hypocrite in friendship, in love a tyrantâ€”

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Hold! Your funeral oration comes too soon; Pizarro is not dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A swineherd in his youth, he now in manhood treats mankind as swine. Illiterate as an Andalusian muleteer, he cannot even read or write!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Love only reads in the eyes, and knows but to write on the heart. I saw in Pizarro a hero, a leader of menâ€”in thee I see not man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Indulge your sportive mockery, while the sun of our prosperity yet shines. When the thunder rolls, trembleâ€”The tempest is not far distant.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Valverde a prophet!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Are we not in a strange country, where death lies in wait in every plant, in every fruit we pluck to satisfy our hunger? Those whom the sword of the enemy spares, an unwonted climate destroys. Daily the number of our foes encreases, while every sun lights a Spaniard to his grave.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: And does that grieve Valverde? Are not the survivors the heirs of the dead?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And can you think, lady, that the sordid thirst for goldâ€”

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Away, away! Think you I cannot discern the wolf, although the garment of the lamb adorns him? I know ye all. There's not a man in all the camp that speaks his thoughts except the good Las Casas.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Name not the dreamer!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: O, had I known this venerable man in early life, how different might have been my lot!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pizarro then, perhaps, had found more obstacles to fair Elvira's loveâ€”

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: How now! presumptuous priest!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pardon me, lady, but it moves my wonder still, that such a man could ever gain your love. You say you saw a hero. What has Pizarro done to gain the title?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Ask Spain, ask Europe, ask both hemispheres that question. When with a pigmy vessel and one hundred men he quitted Panama, to conquer an unknown world, my heart whispered, "This is a brave man." But when upon the little island Gallo, he drew a line with his sword in the sand, and permitted all to abandon him who chose to pass that line; when only thirteen trusty men swore to follow, and he at their head dedicated himself to death, my heart cried aloud, "A hero!"

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Were fame herself enamoured of Pizarro, she could not sound his praises in loftier key than does Elvira. But believe me, lady, Pizarro's brilliant actions belong only to the past. As long as Alonzo de Molina instructs and leads the enemy, Pizarro's heart will not be gladdened by the shouts of victory. (Trumpets without.) He comes.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Look not confounded. Put on an honest face, man, if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (Without.) Secure himâ€”I will examine him myself.

div.stage: Enter PIZARRO. He stops short on seeing VALVERDE and ELVIRA together. Looks at them alternately with frowning suspicion. VALVERDE bows:â€”ELVIRA laughs.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Why dost thou smile, Elvira?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: To laugh and weep, without being obliged to give a reason, are among the few privileges we women enjoy.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: I will know the cause.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: "I will, I will!" But, unfortunately for your curiosity, I will not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Donna Elvira laughed at my fears.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Fears! What fears?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That the enemy, through superior numbers and the instructions of Alonzo de Molinaâ€”

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Alonzo! Only women, and men more weak than women, could think of danger from a source so mean. The ungrateful traitor! How I once loved that man! His noble mother entrusted him a boy to my protection. He feasted at my tableâ€”he slept in my tent. I saw the spark of heroism in his soul, and hoped to fan it to a flame.â€”Oft when I recounted our first adventuresâ€”what toils we struggled withâ€”what perils we surmountedâ€”how, landed on an unknown coast, famine, fatigue, discord within and thronging foes without, thinned our scanty ranks, while still I stood undaunted and maintained my purpose and my power, in spite of growling mutiny and bold revolt, till with my faithful few I stood victorious!â€”Then would the youth Alonzo, with tears of wonder and delight, fall on my neck, and swear his soul's ambition knew no other leader.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And whose rude foot destroyed the hopeful seed?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Smooth-tongued Las Casas. He it was, with fascinating craft and canting precepts of humanity, raised in Alonzo's mind a visionary enthusiasm, which forced him, as the stripling termed it, to forego his country's claims for those of human nature.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And so become thy enemy and Spain's.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p:
But first, with weariless remonstrance, he strove to win me from my purpose, and wrest the
sword from my determined grasp, calling the Peruvians our brethren.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Heathens our brethren! In that I see Las Casas.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: But when he found that his tears fell on marble, he flew and joined the foe: then, profiting by the lessons he had gained in wronged Pizarro's school, the youth so disciplined and led his new allies, that soon he forced meâ€”Ha! I burn with shame and fury while I own it!â€”in base discomfiture to quit the shore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But the hour of revenge is come.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: It is!â€”With mightier power, a second time I tread Peruvia's strand. Soon shall Alonzo know Pizarro lives.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is yet a question, whether Alonzo lives.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Even now, one of his armour-bearers is made prisoner. He says the foe is full twelve thousand strong, led by Alonzo and a chief called Rolla. This day they sacrifice unto their God. We must profit by their security; attack them unprepared, and make their altars reek with human blood. (Sound of trumpets.) Right! The leaders obey my summons to counselâ€”and thenâ€”to battle! Elvira, retire!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Men are to meet here.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: O, men! men! ungrateful and perverse. O, woman! still affectionate, though wronged. Those beings to whom in prosperity you look for added rapture, and on whose bosoms you seek for rest in adversity, when the pompous follies of your mean ambition is the question, you treat as play-things or as slaves. I shall remain.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Remain, then, and be silent if thou canst.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I shall thinkâ€”and the thoughtful are always silent.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: There's somewhat in her manner latelyâ€” (Pizarro looks sternly and suspiciously at Elvira, who meets him with a commanding and unaltered eye.)

div.stage: Enter LAS CASAS, ALMAGRO, OFFICERS and SOLDIERS. Trumpets without.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: Pizarro, we attend your summons.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Venerable father, welcome! Welcome, friends and fellow-soldiers! The moment has arrived which, to Pizarro's hopes, presents the full reward of our undaunted enterprize and long enduring toils. The enemy to-day, sunk in security, devote themselves to solemn sacrifice. Let us surprize them. Death to the armedâ€”to the defenceless, chains!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Death to the whole unbelieving race.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: For the honor of our faith.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: (Fixing his eye on Valverde.) Blaspheme not! The basis of the Christian faith is love!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: We suffer famine, and the soldiers murmur.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Whilst Alonzo, basking at his ease, mocks at our sufferings.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: You do him wrong. My heart tells me, that the struggles in Alonzo's bosom, between benevolence and patriotism, have left him little ease.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: 'Tis fit Las Casas should defend his pupil.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: He is my pupil, and I glory in him.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Name not the traitor! Are we agreed for battle?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: All! lead us to battle, Pizarro!

sp.speaker: Officers and Soldiers.
sp.p: Battle!

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: What a frightful echo! Battle! Gracious heavens! against whom? Against a king who but yet a few days past stretched out to you the hand of friendship and of peace. Against a people who never wronged the living being their creator formed. A people, who, children of innocence! received you with hospitality and kindness. Generously and freely did they share with you their comforts, their treasures and their homes: you repaid them by fraud, oppression and dishonor. These eyes have witnessed all I speakâ€” as gods you were received; as fiends have you acted.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: They are heathens.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: They are men. Hear me Pizarro! Hear me ye chieftains! And thou all-powerful! whose thunders can rive the adamantive rock, and whose light and warmth can melt the icy mountain into refreshing rivuletsâ€”Oh! let thy power give effect to thy servant's words, as the consciousness of right gives courage to his will! Do not, I implore you, countrymenâ€”do not renew the foul barbarities which your insatiate avarice has inflicted on this wretched, unoffending race. The scenes which I have seen and could describe, would force tears from the eyes of tygers.â€”Hush my sighs â€”drops of bitterness! choak not my utterance!â€”

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: You exaggerate, Las Casas.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: O, would to God I had already said the half of what I know! Donna Elviraâ€”you weep! â€”Alas! does the woe of this people move no other hearts than thine and mine?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: There are no other women here but she and thou.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Close this idle war of words. Time flies, and our opportunity will be lost. Comrades, are you for battle?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We are!

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: O! send me once more to those you call your enemies. O! let me bear the words of penitence and peace, and preach our blessed religion uninterrupted by the cries of blood!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The sword of your hero shall prepare your way.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: God! thou hast anointed me thy servant, not to curse, but to bless. But blessings on these men were blasphemy. No! I curse your purpose, fratricides. I curse the bond of blood by which you are united. May fell division, infamy, and rout, defeat your purpose and rebuke your hopes. I leave you, and forever! No longer will I be the witness of these horrors. In caves and forests will I hide myself. With tygers and with savage beasts commune. And, when we meet before him whose mild doctrines you have this day renounced, tremble at the sight of your accuser! (Going.)

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Las Casas! O, take me with thee, Las Casas!

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: Nay, stay! Be thou the guardian of the innocent. Perhaps thy loveliness may move to pity, where reason and religion plead in vain. Perhaps thou art marked by heaven as the protecting angel of suffering Peru! Exit.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Elvira! wouldst thou leave me?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I am bewildered. I am awaking from a dream. Las Casas has aroused me. O! to my fancy, he appeared, but now, a being supernatural; and youâ€”a herd beneath humanity.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Compassion sometimes becomes a woman.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Humanity alway becomes a conqueror.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Now to prepare our muster and our march. At mid day is the hour of sacrifice. Then, Almagro, march you with the left division through the wood. You, Gonzalo, climb the hills with the right. I push straight forward. If we surprize, we conquer; and if we conquer, the gates of Quito will be open to us.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Then shall we hail thee monarch of Peru!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Not so fast. Ataliba still must retain the shadow of power; Pizarro still appear dependent upon Spain. While the pledge of future peace, his daughter's hand, secures my succession to the throne.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pizarro is both hero and statesman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You mark, Elvira.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: 'Tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Elviraâ€”you seem offended.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Offended?â€”No!â€”Thou knowest thy glory is my idol; and this is most glorious, most just and honorable.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Oh! nothingâ€”mere woman's prattle. Let it not impede the royal hero's course. (Trumpets.) The call of arms invites you. Away! away! ye valiant warriors.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: And go you not with me?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Undoubtedly! I must be the first to hail the future monarch of Peru.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What bringest thou, Davilla?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p:
A prisoner. The guards on yonder hill, among the palms, have surprized an old cacique.
He resisted not; but every word he utters is fraught with bitterness and scorn.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Lead him hither. (Davilla goes out, and returns with Orozimbo in chains and guarded.) Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Where is the leader of this band of robbers?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Madman! Tear out his tongue!

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Or else you'll hear the truth.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (Shewing his poinard.) Shall I not plunge this to his heart?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Does your army boast many such heroes as this?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Grey-headed ruffian, thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: That have I known since first I knew to live.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Less insolence perhaps had saved thy life.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: My life is a withered treeâ€”it is not worth preserving.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Purchase our friendship, and our swords shall place thee at the head of thy people.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: That was ever my station in the hour of danger.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: We now march against your army. Be our guide through the wood, and we will load you with treasure.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Dost thou despise my offer?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Compared to mine, thy wealth is beggary. My treasures are so great, I cannot ask the bounteous gods for more.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Indeed! In what do they consist?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p:
First of my wealth, I count two valiant sons, armed for their country. The rest consists
of eighty active years spent in that country's service; these are the treasures Orozimbo countsâ€” for every day a deed of righteousness.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: 'Tis not such wealth we seek, or question of.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: No. Else had you never vexed the troubled seas, or stained these shores with blood. The treasures of the soul are found at home.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: How numerous is your army?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Count the trees of the forest.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Which is the weakest part of your camp?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: It has no weak partâ€”on every side 'tis fortified by justice.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: At what hour do you offer sacrifice to your God?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: The sacrifice of thankful hearts, every hour of the day.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Where have you concealed your wives and children?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: In the hearts of their husbands and fathers.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Knowest thou Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Know him! The benefactor of our nation!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: By what has he merited that title?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: By being the reverse of thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Who is this Rolla, joined in command with Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: The first of heroes, and the best of men! The kinsman of the king, the idol of the army, the friend of Alonzo, the lover of Cora; a lover who gave his beloved to the man she loved, and loved that man for her sake.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Romantic savage!â€”I shall meet this Rolla soon.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Thou hadst better not! Thou art not fit for death.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Silence, old savage.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Why silence? When I address my God, I speak the truth; and shall I fear to speak the truth to man?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Silence, or tremble.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Beardless robber! I never yet have trembled before Godâ€”why should I tremble before man? before thee, thou less than man?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Another word thou heathen dog, and I strike thee to the earth. (Draws his dagger.)

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Strike, Christian! Then boast among your fellowsâ€”"I too have murdered a Peruvian!"

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To hell with thee! (Stabs him.)

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Hold! (Soldiers support Orozimbo.)

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Could'st thou longer have endured his insults?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: And therefore should he die untortured?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Young man, you have lost a useful lesson; you might have seen with what cruelty vengeance inflicts torments, and with what patience virtue bears them.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: (Supporting Orozimbo's head upon her bosom.) O, you are monsters all! Look up thou martyred innocentâ€”look up once more, and bless me ere thou diest. God! how I pity thee!

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Pity me! me! so near my happiness.â€” My wife beckons me to the land of our fathers!â€” The sun smiles!â€”Spaniardsâ€”heaven turn your hearts and bless you!â€” (Borne off, dying, by two Soldiers.)

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Valverdeâ€”Is not that the death of a christian?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Follow me, friends! Each to his post; and, ere Peruvia's god shall sink beneath the main, the Spanish banners, bathed in blood, shall float above the walls of Quito. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is it presumption, that my hopes gain strength as Pizarro's overbearing cruelty encreases?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I am mad with terror and remorse! Would I could fly these dreadful scenes!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Might not Valverde's true attachment be thy refuge?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: What would'st thou do to deserve me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: One well aimed blow might save Peruâ€” avenge Elvira's injuries!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Save this innocent people? Restore a nation's happiness?â€”Goâ€”goâ€”leave me alone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: One word, and he lies bleeding at thy feet.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: No!â€”Shall murder also stand upon my soul? No!â€”Fie, Elvira! even for a moment to counsel with this unworthy traitor! Pizarro will abandon me!â€”me, who for his sake have sacrificed â€”Oh, God! what have I not sacrificed to him?â€”Abandon me? No! I abandon him! â€”I loved the hero; but despise the robber! My love is pastâ€”but holdâ€”try him once more, Elvira. And if he is lost to reason and humanityâ€” abandon his unhallowed camp; nay, cast him to the dust from which he sprung.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: A wood.â€”CORA, sitting at the root of a tree, is playing with her CHILD. ALONZO looks over them with delight.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Looks smiling at the child and then at Alonzo.) Now confess, does he resemble thee or not?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: He looks like thee much more.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: No, noâ€”his hairâ€”the colour of his eyes! O! my lord's image, and my heart's adored!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: The little urchin robs me of thy love.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O no, Alonzo!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: At least he steals caresses which once were mineâ€”and mine alone.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: When the mother caresses her child, she never forgets the father. I live but in him and thee. Look, Alonzo! I am sure he will speak soon; then will be the last of the three great holidays allowed by nature's sanction to the fond mother's heart.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: What are these three?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: When first the white blossoms of his teeth appear, breaking the crimson buds that did encase them, that is a day of joy; next, when from his father's arms he runs without support, and clings, laughing and delighted, to his mother's knee, that is the mother's heart's next holliday. And sweeter still the third, whene'er his little stammering tongue shall utter the grateful sound of father! mother! O! that is the dearest joy of all!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Beloved Cora!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O, my Alonzo! daily will we pour our thanks to heaven!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: To heaven, and Rolla!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Art thou not happy?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Can Cora ask that question?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Why then of late so restless on thy couch? Why do thy sighs torture thy Cora's car?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Must not I fight with my brethren?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: With those who would destroy us. All men are brethren.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Should they prove victorious?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: I will fly and meet thee on the mountains.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Fly!â€”with thy infant in thy arms?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Why not? Think you a mother, when she flies from danger, can feel the weight of her child?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Willingly would I share with you the precious burthen.â€”Coraâ€”dear Coraâ€”wouldst thou set my heart at rest?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Oh yes! yes! yes!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Fly then, now, even to-day, to the mountains, to thy aged father, there thou art safe. Then go it as it will, I feel secure. I either bring thee tidings of victory, or come to end my life, with thee, with innocence and nature.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: And to rear up our son to be the deliverer of his country.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: That will we!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Yes, but I cannot leave you, Alonzo. The thought of your danger will chain my feet. The thought of you woundedâ€”aloneâ€”abandoned.â€” No, no, I cannot leave you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Rolla will be with me.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p:
Yes, where the battle rages. Rolla knows to deal wounds, but it is Cora's part to bind them.
He will avenge, not save thee. No, where the husband is, there must the wife be also. I swear, not to leave thee until death!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Remain, then, soul of truth! And may God give us the victory!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Is not our cause just? The protection of heaven is with us.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: If notâ€”I shall die in thy arms.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O, speak not of death.â€”Since I have had thee and this little oneâ€”I cannot think of death.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: O, excellence in all that's great and lovely, in courage, gentleness and truth: my pride, content, my all! Can there on earth be fools who seek for happiness, and pass by love in the pursuit?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Alonzo, I cannot thank youâ€”silence is the language of love and gratitude. (Shouts without.) Does the king approach?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: No, 'tis Rolla, placing the guard which will surround the temple during the sacrifice. The first of heroes, and the best of friends.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (As entering.) Then place them on the hill fronting the Spanish camp.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Rolla! our brother.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Our more than brotherâ€”friend!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Right! A friend who shares your happiness.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Look on this child. If ever he does less for thee than for his fatherâ€”his mother's hate be on him!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p:
Enough, enough! the object of my love was Cora's happiness. I see her happy, and I am
rewarded. Now, Cora, listen to a friend's advice. Fly with thy child, deep in the forest, or to the mountains; here thou art not safe.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Not safe with thee and Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Pizarro's plan is to surprize us. Your presence will impede our efforts.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Impede?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Thou knowest how tenderly we love. If thou art near, our thoughts, our valor will not be our own. No advantage will be pursued that leads us from the spot where you are placed; no succour will be given but for your protection.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Rolla is right. How should I dare to pierce the Spanish ranks, if but one Spaniard should remain behind me, who might cut his way to the spot where my Cora remained defenceless. You must be safe, or Alonzo is no general!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Smiling.) This is flattering to the vanity of the woman, but the wife hears it not.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: And is the mother also deaf?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: My confidence in thee, and in the gods, would have supported me. But for thy peace, my husband, I obey thee.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Thank thee, my Cora. (March without.) Hark! the king approaches to sacrifice. Rolla, is every post prepared against surprize?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: All is prepared.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Then shall Cora, upon the rocky altar of the mountain, in the temple of nature, implore a blessing on the efforts of the husband and the friend.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Yes, Cora, the pious supplications of the trembling wife and mother's heart, rise to the throne of mercy, the most resistless prayer of human homage. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE SECOND.
div.stage: Temple of the sun, with all the magnificence of Peruvian superstition. In the centre an altar.
The WARRIORS, headed by ATALIBA, enter on one side. ROLLA, ALONZO and CORA on the other.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Welcome, Alonzo! Rolla! my kinsman, thy hand. (To Cora.) Heaven bless thee, joyful mother!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: May the sun bless the father of his people!

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: The children's welfare is the father's joy. (Takes the centre of the stage. Alonzo and Cora on his right. Rolla on his left.) Friends, what is the temper of our soldiers?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Their joyful shout is, "The father of his people is with us!"

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: "He shares in our dangers and our toils!"

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: "God and the king!"

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: "Victory or death!"

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: I know my people! When this shield is pierced, not a man but will lend me his breast! But, tell me, where are our enemies?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: In their camp; motionless, but portending mischief. Like the thunder-cloud on the brow of the distant mountain.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Tranquil courage be our safeguard.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: They fight for gold, we for our country.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: A robber leads them to battle, but with us is the beloved of his people.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: And the god of our fathers! Come, friends, prepare for the sacrifice.

div.stage: A SOLEMN PROCESSION commences from the recess of the temple above the altar. The PRIESTS and VIRGINS OF THE SUN arrange themselves on either side. The HIGH PRIEST approaches the altar.

div.l: O glorious sun! Parent of light and life!
Smile on thy children in the day of strife.
As by thy influence from the parent earth
The sap springs upward to the tender flow'r,
So from this soil may confidence and worth,
Arise and swell each heart to meet the coming hour!

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST.
sp.l: May the infants lisping please thee!
As he prays for his father's return.
May the prayers of the aged please thee!
While their hearts for their country burn.

div.stage: (The youngest of the virgins of the sun, presents a basket of flowers to the KING.)

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST.
sp.l: Through prayer the smiles of heaven are won.

sp.speaker: CHORUS. THE WHOLE KNEELING.
sp.l: God of Peru! to thee we kneel. O give
That still thy children in thy smiles may live.

div.stage: (During this, ATALIBA approaches and casts the flowres on the altar.)

sp.speaker: CHORUS. PRIESTS.
sp.l: O give, great God! Some favorable sign
That thou acceptest of our humble praise!
Send forth, O source of heat! a beam benign!
Consume this offering with thy sacred rays.
sp.stage: (A flame descends and consumes the offering.)
ALL RISE AND JOIN IN CHORUS.
sp.l: Triumph! Triumph! Our prayer is heard!
Let shouts of triumph rend the air:
Peruvia's God has heard our prayer!
Now bend the bow and draw the sword,
And "victory or death" be each Peruvian's word!

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: The enemy!

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: How near?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: As I approached their camp from the brow of the hill, I beheld them suddenly rush out.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: We know enough.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Lead the women and children to the place of safety. Exeunt Priests and women.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Oh, Alonzo!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: We shall meet again.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Bless thy son.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: The blessing of heaven be on him and thee.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Haste, hasteâ€”the moments are precious.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Farewell, Alonzo. Remember, thy life is mine.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Sayest thou not a word to me, Cora.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Giving him her hand.) Bring me back Alonzo. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: (Draws his sword.) Now, my brethren, my sons, my friends, I know your valor. Should ill success assail us, be despair the last feeling of your hearts. If successful, let mercy be the first. Alonzo, to you I give to defend the narrow passage of the mountains. On the right of the wood be Rolla's station. For me, straight forward will I march to meet them, and fight until I see my people saved, or they behold their monarch fall. Be the word of battleâ€”God and our native land.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Here, my friend, we separate.â€”Soon, I trust, to meet again in triumph.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Or, perhaps, we part to meet no more. Rolla, a moment's pause; we are yet before our army's strength; one earnest word at parting.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: There is in language now no word but battle.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Yes, one word moreâ€”Cora!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Cora!â€”Speak!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: The next hour brings usâ€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Death or victory!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: It may be victory to oneâ€”death to the other.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Or both may fall.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: If so, my wife and child I bequeath to the protection of heaven and the king. But should I only fall, Rolla, be thou my heir.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Be Cora thy wifeâ€”be thou a father to my child.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Rouse thee, Alonzo! Banish these timid fancies.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Rolla! I have tried in vain, and cannot fly from the foreboding which oppresses me. Thou knowest it will not shake me in the fight: but give me thy promise.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: If it be Cora's will.â€”Yesâ€”I promise.â€”

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Tell her it was my last wish! And bear to her and to my son, my last blessing.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I will.â€”Now then to our posts, and let our swords speak for us.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Yet one moment. Let my body be buried under the palm-tree, where we are wont in the evening to sit, and desert not the place after my death, but do thou and Cora, each evening visit the palm and sit on the grave of your friend.â€” And when my boy breaks a flower from the swerd of the grave, or the wind rustles among the palm-leaves â€”then think of Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Away with these fancies.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Seizing his hand.) Then think on me.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: That will we.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Now, then, away to the fight!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Thee left, I right. (They draw.)

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: For the king and Cora!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: For Cora and the king!

div.head: SCENE FOURTH.
div.stage: A distant view of a Peruvian village. Trees growing from a rocky eminence on one side. Alarms continued. Drums, &c. at a distance.
Enter an OLD BLIND MAN and a BOY.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Hark! I hear the din of battle! Oh, my sight! had I retained my sight, I might now have grasped a sword, and died the death of a soldier.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Shall I lead you back to your hut?

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: No. Are we quite alone?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes. My father is with the army, and my mother I know not where.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: I am anxious for you, poor boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I can stay with you, dear grandfather.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: But should the enemy come, they will drag thee from me, dear boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Impossible, grandfather! for they will see at once that you are old and blind, and cannot do without me.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Poor childâ€”you little know these men. (Cannon heard.) Hark! can you see nothing, boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: We are too low.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Is there no hill near us?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I can climb this rock, and the tree above it.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Haste. (The Boy climbs up.) This is the first fight without me. The day was, when I could bend as stout a bow as that which Rolla bears. But now, now must I hear only how the swords glitter and the shields clashâ€”and, at the sound of the war-horn, I strike my hand upon my thigh, but no longer find a sword.â€”Now, boy, what seest thou?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Dust and smoke. Now the smoke is blown offâ€”I see our people.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Marching forwards?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: They stand.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Do you see the standard of the Incas?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It waves in the midst.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Thanks to the godsâ€”the king lives!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now I see the enemy.â€”Now they mix with our people.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: And fall?â€” (Cannon.)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It thunders and lightens!â€”The standard of the Inca falls.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Come down!â€”Come down!â€”See no more!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Our army retreats.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: My sword! My sword! O glorious sun! Only one hour let thy light reach my eyes!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A small troop comes this wayâ€”

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Spaniards?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The heads of their lances glitterâ€”

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Fly, boyâ€”fly to the mountains.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Will you seek my mother?

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: My grave, boyâ€”my open grave! (They retire up.)

div.stage: Enter ATALIBA, with ORANO and WARRIORS.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: My wound is bound; the hurt is nothing. I may return to the field.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Pardon your servant; but the allotted priest, who attends the sacred banner, has pronounced, that the Inca's blood once shed, no blessing can await the day until he leave the field.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Hard restraint! O, my brave soldiers! Hard, that I may no longer be a witness of their valor. But haste your return to your comrades; I will not keep one soldier from his post. Go, and avenge your fallen brethren. (Exeunt Orano and Warriors.) I will not repine; my own fate is the least anxiety of my heart. It is for you, my people, that I feel and fear.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: I hear an unfortunate. Who is the moaner?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: A wretch abandonedâ€”almost by hope.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Lives the king still?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: He lives.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Then are you not abandoned. Ataliba protects the meanest of his children.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: And who shall protect Ataliba?

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: The gods.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Their anger is upon him.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: That cannot be. He hath never withheld justice or oppressed the weak; he hath never fattened his courtiers with the sweat of the peasants. He hath never shut his hand to the poor, or his car to the unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: God! thou hast thrown into this bitter hour the sweetest moment of my life!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O, father! stranger! see these hideous men that rush upon us yonder.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Ha! Spaniards! And Iâ€”Atalibaâ€”ill-fated fugitive, without a sword to try the ransom of a monarch's life.

div.stage: Enter DAVILLA, ALMAGRO, and SPANISH SOLDIERS.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: 'Tis heâ€”our hopes are answeredâ€”I know him wellâ€”it is the king!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Away! follow with your royal prize.â€” Avoid those Peruvians though in flight. This way we may regain our line. (Exeunt Davilla, Almagro, and Spanish Soldiers, with Ataliba prisoner.)

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: The king! Wretched old man, that could not see his gracious form!â€”Boy, would thou hadst led me to the reach of those ruffian's swords.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Father! all our countrymen are flying here for refuge.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: No!â€”to the rescue of their kingâ€”they will never desert him.

div.stage: Enter PERUVIAN OFFICERS and SOLDIERS, flying across the stage; ORANO following.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Hold, I charge you! Rolla calls you.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: We cannot combat with their dreadful engines.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p:
Hold, recreants! cowards! What, fear ye death? and fear not shame? By my soul's fury, I cleave to the earth the first of you that stirs
â€”or plunge your dastard swords into your leader's heart, that he no more may witness your disgrace. Where is the king?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: From this old man and boy I learn, that the detachment of the enemy, which you observed so suddenly to quit the field, have succeeded in surprizing him; they are yet in sight.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And bear the Inca off a prisoner? Hear this, ye base, disloyal rout! Look there! The dust you see hangs on the bloody Spaniards track, dragging with ruffian taunts your king, your father!â€”Ataliba in bondage. Now fly, and seek your own vile safety, if you can.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Bless the voice of Rolla!â€”and bless the stroke I once lamented, but which now spares these extinguished eyes the shame of seeing the pale trembling wretches, who dare not follow Rolla, though to save the king!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Shrink ye from the thunder of the foeâ€” and fall ye not at this rebuke? Oh! had ye each but one drop of the loyal blood, which gushes to waste through the brave heart of this sightless veteran! Eternal shame pursue you, if you desert me now! But doâ€”alone I goâ€”aloneâ€”to die with glory by my monarch's side!

sp.speaker: Sol's.
sp.p: Rolla! We'll follow thee.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: God and our native land. (Trumpets sound; Rolla rushes out, followed by Orano, Officers and Soldiers.)

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: O, godlike Rolla!â€”And thou sun, send from thy clouds avenging lightning to his aid!â€” Haste, my boy; ascend some height, and tell to my impatient terror what thou seest.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: (Ascends the rock, and from thence into the tree.) Oâ€”now I see themâ€”nowâ€”yesâ€”and the Spaniards turning by the steep.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Rolla follows them?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He doesâ€”he doesâ€”he moves like an arrow!â€”now he waves his arm to our soldiers.â€” (Cannon heard.) Now there is fire and smoke.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Yes, fire is the weapon of those fiends.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The wind blows off the smoke; they are all mixed together.

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Seest thou the king?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yesâ€”Rolla is near him! his sword sheds fire as he strikes!

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: Bless thee, Rolla! Spare not the monsters.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Father! father! The Spaniards flyâ€”Oâ€” now I see the king embracing Rolla. (Waving his cap for joy. Shouts of victory. Flourish of trumpets, &c.)

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: (Falls on his knees.) Fountain of life! how can my exhausted breath bear to thee thanks for this one moment of my life! My boy, come down, and let me kiss thee.â€”My strength is gone!

div.stage: (The Boy having run to the Old Manâ€”)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Let me help you, fatherâ€”you tremble soâ€”

sp.speaker: O. M.
sp.p: 'Tis with transport, boy! It is with transport!â€”

div.stage: (Boy leads the Old Man off. Shouts, flourish, &c.)
Enter ATALIBA, ROLLA, and PERUVIAN OFFICERS and SOLDIERS.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: In the name of my people, the saviour of whose sovereign you have this day been, accept this emblem of his gratitude. (Giving Rolla his sun of diamonds.) The tear that falls upon it may for a moment dim its lustre, yet does it not impair the value of the gift.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: It was the hand of heaven, not mine, that saved the king.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Now, soldier, what news from Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Alonzo's genius soon repaid the panic which broke our ranks; but I fear we have to mourn Alonzo's loss; his eager spirit urged him too far in the pursuit.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: How! Alonzo slain?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: I saw him fall.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Trust me, I beheld him up again and fightingâ€”he was then surrounded and disarmed.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: O! victory, dearly purchased!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: O, Cora! Who shall tell thee this?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Rolla, our friend is lostâ€”our native country saved! Our private sorrows must yield to the public claim for triumph. Now go we to fulfil the first, the most sacred duty which belongs to victoryâ€”to dry the widowed and the orphaned tear of those whose brave protectors have perished in their country's cause.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: A wild retreat among stupendous rocksâ€”CORA and her Child, with other Wives and Children of the Peruvian Warriors, are scattered about the scene in groups.

sp.speaker: 1st. P. Wom.
sp.p: Zuluga, seest thou nothing yet?

sp.speaker: 2d. P. Wom.
sp.p: Yes, two Peruvian soldiers; one on the hill, the other entering a thicket in the vale.

sp.speaker: 3d. P. Wom.
sp.p: One more has passed.â€”He comes â€”but pale and terrified.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: My heart will start from my bosom.

sp.speaker: 1st. Wom.
sp.p: Well! joy or death?

sp.speaker: 1st. Sol.
sp.p: The battle is against us. The king is wounded and a prisoner.

sp.speaker: 1st. Wom.
sp.p: Despair and misery!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (In a faint voice.) And Alonzo?

sp.speaker: 1st. Sol.
sp.p: I saw him not. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1st. Wom.
sp.p: O, whither must we fly?

sp.speaker: 2d. Wom.
sp.p: Deeper into the forest.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: I shall not move.

sp.speaker: 2d Per.
sp.p: Still there is hopeâ€”the battle turns.

sp.speaker: 1st. Wom.
sp.p: Hope?

sp.speaker: 2d. Per.
sp.p: Rolla has rallied the troops.â€”They rush upon the enemyâ€”

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: And Alonzo?

sp.speaker: 2d. Per.
sp.p: I saw him not. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Victory! victory!

sp.speaker: 1st. Wom.
sp.p: Does the king live?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: He livesâ€”Rolla has saved himâ€”saved his country!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: And Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: I saw him not. Exit.

div.stage: (The triumphant march of the army is heard at a distance. The Women and Children go to meet them. The Warriors enter, marching down the rocks, the women strewing flowers before them. They range on each side. The King and Rolla follow, and are met with rapturous and affectionate, respect. Cora, during this scene, with her Child in her arms, runs through the ranks searching and enquiring for Alonzo.)

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Thanks, thanks, my children! I am well; believe it; the blood once stopped, my wound was nothing.

div.stage: (Cora at length approaches Rolla, who appears to have been mournfully avoiding her.)

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Where is Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Falling at the King's feet.) Give me my husband; give this child his father.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: I grieve that Alonzo is not here.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Hoped you to find him?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Most anxiously.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Ataliba, is he not dead?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: No! the gods will have heard our prayers.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Is he not dead, Ataliba?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: He livesâ€”in my heart.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O, king! torture me not thus! Speak out, is this child fatherless?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Dearest Cora! do not thus dash aside the little hope that still remains.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: The little hope! Yet still there is hope! Speak to me, Rolla, you are the friend of truth.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Alonzo has not been found.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Not found! What mean you? Will not you, Rolla, tell me the truth? Oh! let not the lightning linger in its courseâ€”Straight to my heart let it pierce. Say not that he is not found; say, at once, that he is dead.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Then should I say false.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: False! Blessings on thee for that word! But snatch me from this terrible suspense. Lift up thy little hands, my child; perhaps thy innocence may plead better than thy mother's agony.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Alonzo is taken prisoner.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Prisoner! And by the Spaniards? Pizarro's prisoner? Then is he dead.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Hope betterâ€”the richest ransom which our realm can yield, a herald shall this instant bear.

sp.speaker: 1st. P. Wom.
sp.p: Oh! for Alonzo's ransomâ€”our gold, our gems!â€”all! all!â€”Here, dear Coraâ€” here! here!

div.stage: (The Peruvian Women eagerly tear off all their ornaments, and run and take them from their Children, to offer them to Cora.)

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Yes, for Alonzo's ransom they would give all!â€”I thank thee, Father, who hast given me such hearts to rule over!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Now, one boon more, beloved monarch. Let me go with the herald.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Remember, Cora, thou art not a wife only, but a mother too. Hazard not your own honor, and the safety of your infant. Among these barbarians, the sight of thy youth, thy loveliness and innocence would but rivet faster your Alonzo's chains, and rack his heart with added fears for thee. Wait, Cora, the return of the herald.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Teach me how to live till then.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Now we go to offer to the gods, thanks for our victory, and prayers for our Alonzo's safety.

div.stage: The King and Rolla; then the Warriors; then the Women and Children. Last Cora with her Infant.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: What will become of theeâ€”precious treasureâ€”the fountain of thy life is dried up.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Cora, I attend your summons.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O, my child, my boy! hast thou still a father?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Cora, can thy child be fatherless, while Rolla lives?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Will he not soon want a mother too?â€”Or thinkest thou I can survive Alonzo's loss?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Yes! for his child's sake.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Poor child! shall it be nourished by the tears of its mother?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Listen to Alonzo's friendâ€”

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Alonzo's friend! Who was not the friend of Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: His last words before the battleâ€”

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: His last wordsâ€”speak!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: He consigned to me, two precious trustsâ€” his blessing for his son, and his last request to thee.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: His last request! His last!â€”O, name it.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: "If I fall" said he, and grasped my hand, "be Cora thy wife."

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Thy wife!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I gave my word, and we pa â€¢â€¢â€¢ d.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: What a horrid light rushes on me! O, Alonzo! thou hast fallen a victim to thy heart's confidence! Hadst thou been silentâ€”hadst thou not made these fatal charms a legacy toâ€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: What a frightful image has seized thy soul!â€”

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: 'Tis clearâ€”his spirit was ensnared; he was led to the fatal spot where mortal valor could not front a host of murderers. He fellâ€”in vain did he exclaim for help to Rolla. At a distance you looked on and smiled. You could have saved himâ€”couldâ€”but did not.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: O, glorious sun! Can I have deserved this? Cora, rather bid me strike this sword into my heart.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p:
No! live! live for love! for that love thou seekest; whose blossoms are to shoot from the bleeding grave of thy betrayed and slaughtered friend!â€”But thou hast borne to me the last words of my Alonzo! Now hear mine. Sooner shall
this boy draw poison from this tortured breastâ€” sooner would I link me to the pallid corse of the meanest wretch that perished with Alonzo, than he call Rolla fatherâ€”than I call Rolla husband!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Yet call me what I amâ€”thy friend, thy protector!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Distractedly.) Away! I have no protector but my God!â€”With this child in my arms, will I hasten to the field of slaughter. There, with these hands, will I turn up to the light every mangled body. Seeking, however by death disfigured, the sweet smile of my Alonzo.â€”With fearful cries will I shriek out his name, till my veins snap! If the smallest spark of life remains, he will know the voice of his Cora, open for a moment his unshrouded eyes, and bless me with a last look; but if we find him notâ€”Oh! then, my boy, we will to the Spanish camp.â€”That look of thine, will win me passage through a thousand swordsâ€” they too are men. Is there a heart that could drive back a wife that seeks her bleeding husband; or the innocent babe that cries for his imprisoned father? No, no, my child, every where we shall be safe. A wretched mother, bearing a poor orphan in her arms, has nature's passport through the world. Yes, yes, my son, we'll go and seek thy father. Exit with the Child.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (After a pause of agitation.) Could I have merited one breath of thy reproaches, Cora, I should be the wretchâ€”I think I was not formed to be. Her safety must be my present purposeâ€” then to convince her she has wronged me!

div.head: SCENE THIRD.
div.stage: PIZARRO, traversing the scene in gloomy and furious agitation.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Well, capricious idol, fortune, be my ruin thy work and boast. To myself I will still be true. Yet ere I fall, grant me thy smile to prosper in one act of vengeance, and be that smile Alonzo's death.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Who's there? Who dares intrude? Why do my guards neglect their duty?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Your guards did what they could; but they knew their duty better, than to enforce authority when I refused obedience.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: And what is your desire?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: To see how a hero bears misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Why didst thou not see me in the midst of my flying army, when, with this arm, I struck the fugitives to the earth? Thou shouldst have seen me amidst my o'erpowered soldiers, when the heads of thousands sunk lowâ€”Then stood Pizarro like a rock amidst the waters, nor bowed his head even to destiny.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I doubt not thy greatness in the roar of battle or the tumult of defeat. But to know a hero thoroughly, I must see him in his tent, and alone.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Here seest thou me. Am I humbled by defeat? Do you hear a fruitless complaint from my lips?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Fie! Complaint! None but priests and women complain.â€”But thy brow is dark. Thou art not collected and serene.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Shall I rejoice that the bravest hearts of my followers have been pierced by the spears of the foe?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Cold and silent shouldst thou be, as the night that follows the storm. The morning breaks, and, with strength renewed, reanimated by the beams of the new sun, the hero walks forth, and is again himself.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Woman!â€”Why on this day were not all my men like thee?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Then had my hand this day placed the crown of Quito on thy head.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Oh, Elvira! the flame of my hope glimmers weakly, while the scourge of my life, Alonzo de Molina, directs the power of Peru.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Pizarro, I am come to probe the hero farther; not now his courage, but his magnanimity â€”Alonzo is your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Valverde saw him, even now, brought in chains to the camp.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Alonzo in my power!â€”Oh, then, I am the conqueror! The power of Peru is overthrown!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Believe me, you raise my impatience to see the man before whom Pizarro trembles without hope.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Guards!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Bring hither the Spanish prisoner.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: What shall be his fate?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Death!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Shame on thee! Shall the world say, that Pizarro could not conquer, until he had murdered Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Be it saidâ€”I care not. His fate is sealed.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Follow then thy will; but, mark me, if basely thou dost shed the blood of this brave youth, Elvira's lost to thee forever.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Why this interest for a stranger? What is Alonzo's fate to thee?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: His fateâ€”nothing! Thy gloryâ€”every thing! Thinkest thou I could love thee, stript of fame, of honor, and a just renown? Know me better.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Thou shouldst have known me better. Thou shouldst have known, that, once provoked to hate, I am forever fixed in vengeance.

div.stage: (ALONZO is brought in, chained and guarded. ELVIRA observes him with attention.)

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Welcome, Don Alonzo de Molina; it is long since we saw each other.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: And yet we ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ too soon, Pizarro.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Thy looks are mended since our parting.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Yet have I not fattened on the blood and spoil of the unoffending.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What is thy secret, midst the toils of war, still to preserve the bloom of careless ease?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Thou wilt not profit by it. Whatever the hardships or the cares of war, peace reigns unshaken here. (Points to his heart.)

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Sarcastic boy!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Thou art answered rightly. Why sport with the unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: We will no longer sport then. Alonzo, to-morrow thou diest.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Pizarroâ€”no!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Hence!â€”or dread my anger.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I will not hence, nor do I dread thy anger.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Generous lady! Spare thy unavailing pity. Seek not to thwart the tyger with his prey beneath his fangs.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Audacious rebel! Thou, a renegado from thy monarch and thy God!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Art thou not, tell me, a deserter from thy country's legionsâ€”and, with vile heathens leagued, hast thou not warred against thy native land?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: No! Deserter I am none! I was not born among robbers! pirates! murderers!â€” When those legions, lured by the abhorred lust of gold, and by thy foul ambition urged, forgot the honor of Castilians, and forsook the duties of humanity, they forsook me. I have not warred against my native land, but against those who have usurped its power. The banners of my country, when first I followed arms beneath them, were Justice, Faith and Mercy. If these are beaten down and trampled under footâ€”I have no country, nor exists the power entitled to reproach me with revolt.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: The power to judge and punish thee, at least, exists.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Where are my judges?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Thou wouldst appeal to the war council?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: If the good Las Casas have yet a seat there, yes; if not, I appeal to heaven!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: And to impose upon the folly of Las Casas, what would be the excuses of thy treason?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: The folly of Las Casas!â€”Such, doubtless, his mild precepts seem to thy hard-hearted wisdom! O! would I might have lived as I will die, a sharer in the follies of Las Casas!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p:
With him I should not need to urge the foul barbarities which drove me from your side; but I would gently lead him by the hand through all the lovely fields of Quito; there, in many a spot where late was barrenness and waste, I would show him how now the opening blossom, blade, or perfumed bud, sweet bashful pledges of delicious harvest, wafting their incense to the ripening sun, give cheerful promise to the hope of industry. This, I would say, is my work! Next I should tell how hurtful customs, and superstitions strange and sullen, would often scatter and dismay the credulous minds of these deluded innocents; and then would I point out to him, where now, in clustered villages, they live like brethren, social and confiding, while through the burning day content sits basking on the cheek of toil, till laughing pastime leads them to the hour of restâ€”this too is mine!â€”And prouder yetâ€”at that still pause between exertion and repose, belonging not to pastime, labor, or to rest, but unto him who sanctions and ordains them all, I would show him many an eye, and many a hand, by gentleness from error won, raised in pure devotion to the true and only God!â€”this too, I could tell him is Alonzo's work!â€”Then would Las Casas clasp me in his aged arms; from his
uplifted eyes a tear of gracious thankfulness would fall upon my head, and that one blessed drop would be to me at once this world's best proof, that I had acted rightly here, and surest hope of my creator's mercy and reward hereafter.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Thou art what thou ever wastâ€”an enthusiast.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: When this enthusiasm abandons me, I shall become worthyâ€”of Pizarro's friendship.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Proud boy. Away and prepare for death.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I am always prepared.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: The first beams of to-morrow's sun shall see thee die.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Thy â€¢â€¢â€¢ geance is hasty. I thank thee for it. (Going.)

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Hold Alonzo!â€”Pizarro, this man shall not die.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Art thou mad?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: If not justly, at least, act greatly. Name not thy country's wrongsâ€”'tis plain they have no share in thy resentment. Thy fury against this man is private hate, and deadly personal revenge; if this be soâ€”and even now thy detected conscience in that look avows itâ€”profane not the name of justice or thy country's cause, but let him arm, and bid him to the field on equal terms.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What! arm his hand again to shed the blood of his brethren?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Robbers were never my brethren.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Away! Thou knowest thy sentence.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I do. For thee, lady, accept my thanks. This camp is not thy proper sphere. Wert thou among yon savages, as they are called, thou wouldst find companions more congenial to thy heart. For there reigns nature and humanity.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: How I admire this man!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Soon mayest thou say, I did admire him.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Meanest thou he will be dead?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: As surely as the sun shall rise.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Pizarroâ€”spare him.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Again Elvira?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Yes, and a thousand times again. Let me be the instrument of his salvation, and a thousand times will you bless me for sparing you the curses of a world. Think, Pizarro, think of the fame you have gained. All Europe, resounds with thy deeds. "He landed," they cry, "with a handful of men in a strange land: after having conquered dangers innumerable of unknown seas, he rendered the arms of Spain victorious over a mighty kingdom.â€”He is a hero!"

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: And if I crush the only obstacle to my complete success, what will they say?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: They will say, "Pizarro trembled before Alonzo de Molina; chance gave him Alonzo in chains, and he meanly murdered, like a cowardly assassin, the man he could not conquer."

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Elvira, no more! Leave me.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Pizarro, you no longer love me.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: It is not so, Elvira. But what might I not suspect.â€”This wondrous interest for a stranger!â€”Take back thy reproach.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: No, Pizarro; as yet I am not lost to youâ€” one string still remains, and binds me to your fate. Do not, I conjure youâ€”do not for thine own sake, tear it asunderâ€”shed not Alonzo's blood!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: My resolution is fixed.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Even though that moment lost you Elvira forever?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Pizarro, remember the sacrifices I have made for thy sake. Have I not shared all thy perils, heavy storms at sea, and frightful 'scapes on shore? Even on this dreadful day, amid the rout of battle, who remained firm and constant at Pizarro's side? Who presented her bosom, as his shield, to the assailing foe?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: 'Tis truly spoken all. In love thou art thy sex's miracleâ€”in war the soldier's patternâ€” and, therefore, my whole heart, and half my acquisitions are thy right.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Convince me I possess the firstâ€”I exchange all title to the latter, forâ€”mercy to Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: No more!â€”Had I intended to prolong his doom, each word thou utterest now would hasten on his fate.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Alonzo then at morn will die?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Thinkest thou yon sun will set? As surely at his rising shall Alonzo die.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Then be it doneâ€”the string is crackedâ€” sundered forever. But mark meâ€”thou hast heretofore had cause, 'tis true, to doubt my resolution, however offendedâ€”but mark me nowâ€”the lips which, cold and jeering, barbing revenge with rancorous mockery, can insult a fallen enemy, shall never more receive the pledge of love; the arm unshaken by its bloody purpose, which shall assign to needless torture the victim who avows his heart; never more shall press the hand of faith! â€”Pizarro, scorn not my wordsâ€”beware you slight them not!â€”I feel how noble are the motives which now animate my thoughtsâ€”who could not feel as I do, I condemnâ€”who, feeling so, yet would not act as I shall, I despise!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (After a pause, looking at her with an affected smile of contempt.) I have heard thee, Elvira, and I know well the noble motives which inspire theeâ€”fit advocate in virtue's cause!â€”Believe me, I pity thy tender feelings for the youth Alonzo! â€”He dies at sun-rise! Exit.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: 'Tis well! 'tis just I should be humbledâ€” I had forgot myself, and in the cause of innocence assumed the tone of virtue. 'Twas fit I should be rebukedâ€”and by Pizarro. Fall, fall, ye few reluctant drops of weaknessâ€”the last these eyes shall ever shed. How a woman can love, Pizarro, thou hast known too wellâ€”how she can hate, thou hast yet to learn. Yes, thou undaunted! Thou, whom yet no mortal hazard has appalled! Thou, who on Panama's brow didst make alliance with the raging elements, that tore the silence of that horrid nightâ€”when thou didst follow, as thy pioneer, the crashing thunder's drift, and stalking o'er the trembling earth, didst plant thy banner by the red volcano's mouth! Thou, who, when battling on the sea, and thy brave ship was blown to splinters, wast seenâ€”as thou didst bestride a fragment of the smoking wreckâ€”to wave thy glittering sword above thy headâ€”as thou wouldst defy the world in that extremity!â€”Come fearless manâ€”now meet the last and fellest peril of thy lifeâ€”meet! and surviveâ€” an injured woman's fury, if thou canst. Exit.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: A Dungeon, in a cavern of the Rock, near the Spanish Camp.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: For the last time, through the cleft dungeon's roof, I now behold the quivering lustre of the stars. Despise death. So spoke the enlightened among the Greeks and Romansâ€”heathens confident in wisdom. And shall a christian tremble?â€”The vigorous youth struggles against a premature deathâ€”a death in the morning of life. No, Alonzo, date not thy life, which thou hast run, by the mean reckoning of the hours and days which thou hast breathed: a life spent worthily, should be measured by a nobler lineâ€”by deeds of usefulness and hours of bliss.â€”Deeds which have made a nation happy, and hours enriched by Cora's loveâ€”Cora!â€”Ah, there I draw upon the cord that binds me to the world!â€”My wife! my child! â€”Here the tears of love hold me, and there the smiles of innocence. Yes, Cassius, thou wast not a husband! Seneca, thou wast not a father! Loud cries the voice of nature, "Live"â€”and my heart re-echoes the tone.â€”Yes!â€”Lord of my destiny! I wish to live!

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Don Alonzo de Molina, here are refreshments for you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Who sends you?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: I am here on guard.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Am I to thank you for this kindness?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: No. Your fate makes my heart ach when I remember your former goodness to the soldiery â€”but I cannot help you. I am poor. Donna Elvira sends this refreshment.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Return it with my thanks.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Will you not taste the wine?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I only drink water.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: But in your situationâ€”it will give you courage to meet your fate.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: My friend, I pity the wretch who has no other source from whence to draw courage. Take the wineâ€”the night is coldâ€”it may do thee good.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: You are a noble gentleman Don Alonzo. I could lament your fate, but that it is a sin to pity a heathen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Poor fellowâ€”he knows not what he says! Father of the afflicted! thy refreshing streams quicken the flowers at the foot of the Pyrennees as well as at the base of the Cordilleras. Thou hast placed the cross upon our altars as the token of mercy, but thou smilest on the sun, which adorns the bosom of the Incas.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Don Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Donna Elvira! Such a visitâ€”at this hour?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: When we hasten to relieve the oppressed we count not the hours.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: It is the last of my life.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I say to thee, "No."

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Pizarro has sworn my death.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: And I, thy life.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I thank thee, but I know to die.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Dost thou suffer willingly?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: If I answered in the affirmative, I should deceive both myself and thee.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Thou art married. Wouldst thou make thy wife a widow?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: My destiny is in the hand of my God.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Such are the words of those who dare not govern their own fortunes. Hast thou children?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: One pledge of the purest love.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Wouldst thou make thy child an orphan?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: O, my Fernando!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Alonzo, thou art a true hero, thou art the benefactor of thy fellow-men. Thou hast been the guardian angel of Peru and hast added the blessings of science to the blessings which nature and innocence had already bestowed on that region: and wilt, thou now without a struggle quit thy post, when one manly exertion could save an unoffending people from destruction?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: What meanest thou?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: The destroyer of Peru will to-morrow be the murderer of Alonzo. Take this dagger and follow me. Pizarro now sleeps in his tent. His death will spread confusion through the camp, aided by which we may escape to the Peruvians. There shall I feel the joyful tears of thy wife upon my cheek, and hear thy child lisp the name of his father. Alonzo, follow me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Murder a sleeping man?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Thy bitterest enemy.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Over my bitterest enemy would I cast my shield, to protect him from harm while he slept.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Not thy foe alone, but the foe of mankind. Determine.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I am resolved.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Then follow me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: To the rack sooner than to dishonor.â€” There was a time when this Pizarro loved me: when each danger of the field, and each pleasure of the board were shared with Alonzo. A hundred times have I slept by his sideâ€”and shall I, sleeping, kill him?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: He has torn asunder every band which united you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Except the remembrance of past kindness.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Enthusiast! I abandon thee. Yet bethink theeâ€”the morning's grey already appears in the eastâ€”its red is the signal of death. I will leave thee for a few minutes and return, if Pizarro wakes not, to learn thy last resolve. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Alonzo's resolves are ever the same, unchangeable as the nature of virtue. God be with my wife!â€”God and Rolla! (Retires into the cave.)

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (Without.) I must speak with him.

div.stage: Enter SOLDIER, and ROLLA as a Monk.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: You must not, father.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: He is my friend.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Not if he were your brother.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: What is to be his fate?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: He dies at sunrise.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Ha!â€”Then I am come in time.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Justâ€”to witness his death.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Soldierâ€”I must speak with him.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Backâ€”back. It is impossible!â€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I do intreat you, but for one moment!

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: You intreat in vainâ€”my orders are most strict.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Look on this wedge of massive goldâ€”look on these precious gems. In thy own land, they will be wealth for thee and thine, beyond thy hope or wish. Take themâ€”they are thineâ€”let me pass one minute with Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Away!â€”wouldst thou corrupt me?â€”Me! â€”an old Castilian!â€”I know my duty better.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Soldier!â€”hast thou a wife?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Hast thou children?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Fourâ€”honest, lively boys.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Where didst thou leave them?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: In my native villageâ€”even in the cot where myself was born.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Dost thou love thy children and thy wife?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Do I love them? God knows my heartâ€” I do.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Soldier! imagine thou wert doomed to die a cruel death in this strange land: what would be thy last request?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: That some of my comrades should carry my dying blessing to my wife and children.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Oh! but if that comrade was at thy prison gateâ€”and should there be toldâ€”thy fellow-soldier dies at sun-riseâ€”yet thou shalt not for a moment see himâ€”nor shalt thou bear his dying blessing to his poor children, or his wretched wife. What wouldst thou think of him, who thus could drive thy comrade from thy door?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Alonzo has a wife and a childâ€”I am come but to receive for her, and for her babe, the last blessing of my friend.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Go inâ€” (Retires.)

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Oh! holy nature! thou dost never plead in vain. There is not, of our earth, a creature bearing form, and life, human or savageâ€”native of the forest wild, or giddy airâ€”around whose parent bosom, thou hast not a cord entwined of power to tie them to their offspring's claims, and at thy will to draw them back to thee. On iron pinion's borneâ€”the blood-stained vulture cleaves the storm. Yet, is the plumage closest to her heart, soft as the cygnet's down, and o'er her unshelled brood, the murmuring ring-dove sits not more gentle!â€”Yes!â€”now he is beyond the porch, barring the outer gate!â€”Alonzo!â€”Alonzo!â€” my friend! Ha!â€”in gentle sleep!â€”Alonzoâ€” rise!â€”

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: How!â€”Is my hour elapsed?â€”Well, (Returning from the recess.) I am ready.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Alonzoâ€”know me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: What voice is that?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: 'Tis Rolla's.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Rolla!â€”my friend!â€” (Embraces him.) Heavens! how couldst thou pass the guard? Did this habitâ€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: There is not a moment to be lost in words: â€”this disguise I tore from the dead body of a friar, as I passed our field of battleâ€”it has gained me entrance to thy dungeon; now take it thou, and fly.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: And Rollaâ€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Will remain here in thy place.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: And die for me!â€”No!â€”Rather eternal tortures rack me.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p:
I shall not die, Alonzo. It is thy life Pizarro seeks, not Rolla'sâ€”and from my prison soon will thy arm deliver me;â€”or, should it be
otherwiseâ€”I am as a blighted plantain standing alone amid the sandy desert. Nothing seeks or lives beneath my shelter. Thou art a husband and a fatherâ€”the being of a lovely wife and helpless infant hang upon thy life.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Wouldst thou make me the cowardly murderer of my friend? Wouldst thou give me a life embittered by torments inexpressible?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Noâ€”I give you to joy and Cora. You shall shed a tear at the remembrance of Rolla, but it will be as one drop of bitterness in the cup of your overflowing bliss.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Can a friend thus torture me?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I could not bring thee a word of greeting from Cora. She knew no one around her. Thy return alone can preserve her life.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: O, God!â€”Cora!â€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: If thou art yet irresolute, Alonzoâ€”now heed me wellâ€”I think thou hast not known that Rolla ever pledged his word, and shrunk from its fulfilment. And, by the heart of truth I swear, if thou art proudly obstinate to deny thy friend the transport of preserving Cora's life, in theeâ€” no power that sways the will of man shall stir me hence;â€”and thou wilt but have the desperate triumph, of seeing Rolla perish by thy sideâ€”with the assured conviction, that Cora, and thy child, are lost forever.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Oh! Rolla!â€”You distract me!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p:
A moment's further pause, and all is lost â€”the dawn approachesâ€”fear not for meâ€”I will treat with Pizarro, as for surrender and submission;â€”I shall gain time, doubt notâ€”while thou, with a chosen band, passing the secret way, mayest at night returnâ€”release thy friend, and bear him
back in triumph. Yesâ€”hastenâ€”dear Alonzo! â€”Even now I hear the frantic Cora call thee!â€” Haste! haste! haste!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Rolla, I fear your friendship drives me from honor, and from right.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Did Rolla ever counsel dishonor to his feiend?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Oh! my preserver! (Embracing him.)

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I feel thy warm tears dropping on my cheek. Go!â€”I am rewarded. (Throws the friar's garment over Alonzo.) There! conceal thy face; and that they may not clank, hold fast thy chains. Nowâ€”God be with thee!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: At night we meet again. Thenâ€”so aid me heaven! I return to saveâ€”orâ€”perish with thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rol.
