sp.p: (Alone.) He has passed the outer porch. He is safe! He will soon embrace his wife and child! Now, Cora, didst thou not wrong me? This is the first time throughout my life I ever deceived manâ€”Forgive me, God of truth! if I am wrong.â€”Alonzo flatters himself that we shall meet againâ€”Yesâ€”there! (Lifting his hands to Heaven.)â€”assuredly we shall meet again: there possess in peace, the joys of everlasting love, and friendshipâ€”on earth, imperfect and embittered.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Now, Alonzoâ€”ha!â€”Who art thou?â€” Where is Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Alonzo's fled.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Fled!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Yesâ€”and he must not be pursued. Pardon this roughness, (Seizing her hand.)â€”but a moment's precious to Alonzo's flight.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: What if I call the guard?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Do soâ€”Alonzo still gains time.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: What if thus I free myself? (Shows a dagger.)

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Strike it to my heart. Still, with the convulsive grasp of death, I'll hold thee fast.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Release me. I give my faith, I neither will alarm the guard, nor cause pursuit.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: At once, I trust thy word.â€”A feeling boldness in those eyes assures me that thy soul is noble.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: What is thy name? Speak freely. By my order the guard is removed beyond the outer porch.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: My name is Rolla.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: The Peruvian leader?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I was so yesterdayâ€”to-day, the Spaniard's captive.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: And friendship for Alonzo moved to this act?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Alonzo is my friend.â€”I am prepared to die for him. Yet is the cause a motive stronger far than friendship.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: One only passion else could urge such generous rashness.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And that isâ€”

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Love.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: True!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Gallant! ingenuous Rolla!â€”Know that my purpose here was thine; and were I to save thy friendâ€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: How! a woman blessed with gentleness and courage, and yet not Cora!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Does Rolla think so meanly of all female hearts?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Not soâ€”you are better and worse than we are.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: To save thee, Rolla, from the tyrant's vengeanceâ€”restore thee to thy native landâ€”and thy native land to peaceâ€”wouldst thou not rank Elvira with the good?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: To judge the action I must know the means.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Take this dagger.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: How to be used?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I will conduct thee to the tent where fell Pizarro sleepsâ€”the scourge of innocenceâ€”the terror of thy raceâ€”the fiend that desolates thy afflicted country.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Have you not been injured by Pizarro?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Deeply as scorn and insult can infuse their deadly venom.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And you ask that I should murder him in his sleep?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Would he not have murdered Alonzo in his chains? He that sleeps and he that's bound are equally defenceless. Hear me, Rollaâ€”So may I prosper in this perilous act, as, searching my full heart, I have put by all rancorous motive of private vengeance there, and feel that I advance to my dread purpose in the cause of human nature, and at the call of sacred justice.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: The God of justice sanctifies no evil as a step towards good. Great actions cannot be atchieved by wicked means.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Then, Peruvian! Since thou dost feel so coldly for thy country's wrongs, this hand, though it revolt my soul, shall strike the blow.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Then is thy destruction certain, and for Peru, thou a stranger, perishest!â€”Give me the dagger!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Now follow me;â€”but firstâ€”and dreadful is the hard necessityâ€”you must strike down the guard.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: The soldier who was on duty here?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Yes, himâ€”else, seeing thee, the alarm will be instant.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And I must stab that soldier as I pass? Take back thy dagger.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Rolla!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: That soldier, mark me, is a man. All are not men that bear the human form. He refused my prayersâ€”refused my goldâ€”denying to admit meâ€”till his own feelings bribed him. For my nation's safety, I would not harm that man!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Then he must be with usâ€”I will answer for his safety.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Be that plainly understood between us;â€” for whatever betide our enterprize, I will not risk a hair of that man's headâ€”he is my brother.

div.head: SCENE SECOND.
div.stage: PIZARRO on a couch, in disturbed sleep.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (In his sleep.) No mercy, traitor.â€”Now at his heart!â€”Stand off there, you.â€”Let me see him bleed!â€”Ha! ha! ha!â€”Let me hear that groan again.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: There!â€”Now, lose not a moment.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: You must leave me now. This scene of blood fits not a woman's presence.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: But a moment's pause mayâ€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Go!â€”Retire to your own tentâ€”and return not hereâ€”I will come to you.â€”Be you not known in this business, I implore you!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I will withdraw the guard that waits.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Now have I in my power, the accursed destroyer of my country's peace; yet tranquilly he rests. God!â€”Can this man sleep?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (In his sleep.) Away! away!â€”Hideous fiends!â€”Tear not my bosom thus!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: No:â€”I was in errorâ€”the balm of sweet repose he never more can know. Look here, ambitious fools!â€”Ye, by whose inhuman pride, the bleeding sacrifice of nations is held as nothingâ€” behold the repose of the guilty! He is at my mercyâ€”and one blow!â€”No!â€”my heart and hand refuse to act; Rolla cannot be an assassin!â€” Yet Elvira must be saved! (Approaches the couch.) Pizarro! awake!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (Starts up.) Who?â€”Guards!â€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Speak notâ€”another word is thy death.â€” Call not for aid!â€”this arm will be swifter than thy guards.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Who art thou? and what is thy will?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I am thine enemy! Peruvian Rolla! Thy death is not my will, or I could have slain thee sleeping.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Speak, what else?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Now thou art at my mercyâ€”answer me! Did a Peruvian ever yet wrong or injure thee, or any of thy nation? Didst thou, or any of thy nation, ever yet show mercy to a Peruvian in your power? Now shalt thou feelâ€”and, if thou hast a heart, thou'lt feel it keenly!â€”a Peruvian's vengeance! (Drops the dagger at his feet.) There!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Is it possible? (Walks aside, confounded.)

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Can Pizarro wonder at this? I thought forgiveness of injuries had been the Christian's precept. Thou seest, at least, it is the Peruvian's practice.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Rolla, thou hast, indeed, surprized, subdued me. (Walks again aside, as in irresolute thought.)

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p:
Is it done? Is he dead? (Sees Pizarro.)
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ â€”still living! Then I am lost! and for you, wretched Peruvians! mercy is no more! Oh! Rolla! treacherous, or cowardly?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: How! Can it be, thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Away! Elvira speaks, she knows not what! Leave me, (To Elvira.) I conjure you, with Pizarro.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: How!â€”Rolla, dost thou think I shall retractâ€”or that I meanly will deny, that in thy hand I placed a poinard to be plunged into that tyrant's heart?â€”No!â€”My sole regret is, that I trusted to thy weakness, and did not strike the blow myself. Too soon thou wilt learn that mercy to that man, is direst cruelty to all thy race!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Guard! quick! a guard!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Yes, a guard! I call them too! And soon I know they ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ me to my death. But think not, Pizarro, the fury of thy flashing eyes shall awe me for a moment!â€”Nor think that woman's anger, or the feelings of an injured heart prompted me to this design. No! Had I been only influenced soâ€”thus failing, shame and remorse would weigh me down. But though defeated and destroyed, as now I am, such is the greatness of the cause that urged me, I shall perish, glorying in the attempt, and my last breath of life shall speak the proud avowal of my purposeâ€”to have rescued millions of innocents from the blood-thirsty tyranny of oneâ€”by ridding the insulted world of thee.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Had the act been noble as the motiveâ€” Rolla had not shrunk from its performance.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Seize this discovered fiend who sought to kill your leader.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Touch me not, at the peril of your souls; â€”I am your prisoner, and will follow you. But thou, their triumphant leader, shalt hear me. Yet, firstâ€”for thee, Rolla, accept my forgiveness: even had I been the victim of thy nobleness of heart, I should have admired thee for it. But 'twas myself provoked my doomâ€”thou wouldst have shielded me. Let not thy contempt follow me to the grave. Didst thou but know the spell-like arts, by which this hypocrite first undermined the virtue of a guiltless heart! how, even in the pious sanctuary wherein I dwelt, by corruption and fraud, he practised upon those in whom I most confidedâ€”till my distempered fancy led me, step by step, into the abyss of guiltâ€”

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Why am I not obeyed?â€”Tear her hence!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Tis pastâ€”but didst thou know my story, Rolla, thou wouldst pity me.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: From my soul I do pity thee!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Villains! drag her to the dungeon!â€”prepare the torture instantly!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Soldiersâ€”but a moment moreâ€”'tis to applaud your generalâ€”it is to tell the astonished world, that, for once, Pizarro's sentence is an act of justice: yes, rack me with the sharpest tortures that ever agonized the human frame; and when thou shalt bid them tear me to death, hoping that thy unshrinking ears may at last be feasted with the music of my cries, I will not utter one shriek or groanâ€”but to the last gasp, my body's patience shall deride thy vengeance, as my soul defies thy power.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (Endeavoring to conceal his agitation.) Hearest thou the wretch whose hands were even now prepared for murder?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Yes! And if her accusation's false, thou wilt not shrink from hearing her; if true, thy barbarity cannot make her suffer the pangs thy conscience will inflict on thee.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p:
And now, farewel, world!â€”Rolla, farewel!â€”Farewel, thou condemned of heaven!â€” (To Pizarro.)â€”for repentance and remorse, I know, will never touch thy heartâ€”we shall meet again.â€”Ha! be it thy horror here, to know that we shall meet hereafter!â€”And when thy parting hour approachesâ€”hark to the knell, whose dreadful beat will strike to thy despairing soul. Then, will vibrate on thy ear, the curses of the cloistered saint from whom you stole me. Then, the last shrieks which burst from my mother's breaking
heart, as she died, appealing to her God against the seducer of her child! Then, the blood-stifled groan of my murdered brotherâ€”murdered by thee, fell monster!â€”seeking atonement for his sister's ruined honorâ€”I hear them now! To me, the recollection's madness! At such an hourâ€” What will it be to thee?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: A moment's more delay, and at the peril of your livesâ€”

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I have spokenâ€”and the last mortal frailty of my life is past. And now, with an undaunted spirit, and unshaken firmness, I go to meet my destiny. That I could not live nobly, has been Pizarro's act. That I will die nobly, shall be my own. Exit, guarded.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Pizarroâ€”I pity thee the tortures of this hour.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: No moreâ€”Explain to me by what miracle thou art here, and here as the protector of Pizarro?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I came to save my friend Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Then thou camest in vain.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: No! Alonzo is in safety.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Thy prisoner.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Fled!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Yes. I have deceived his guard. My friend is safe. I am thy prisoner.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Young man, you force from me my admirationâ€”my esteem.â€”Thou art at liberty.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Thou doest in this, thy duty.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Go, and if we meet again in battleâ€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: We will fight like men.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: I will turn aside and spare thee.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Not so. For thou shalt be the first whom I will seek in the field of battle. Meanwhile farewel. (Goingâ€”returns.) Pizarro, the soldier who guarded Alonzo, has done his dutyâ€”forgive him.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Thou requirest too much.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Grant my request, or I remain. I save or suffer with him.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What, for a private soldier?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: He is a man: a man of whose misfortune I am the cause.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Depart in peace. I forgive him. Rolla, I would we were friends.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Be virtue's friend, and thou art Rolla's.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Ambition! tell me what is the phantom I have follow'd? Where is the one delight which it has made my own? My fame is the mark of envyâ€”my love the dupe of treacheryâ€”my glory eclipsed by the boy I taughtâ€”my revenge defeated and rebuked by the rude honor of a savage foe. And I have suffered him to escape!â€”The strength of the enemy was in my power.â€”Ha!â€”By Heavens! he is still in my power.â€”What, guards! (Going.) Hold, Pizarro, thou hast pledged thy faith. Damnation!â€”But he is a heathen, and with these our priestsâ€”Away, away! damned sophistry!â€”The faith of heroes ever was the same.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: A thick Forest. In the back ground, a Hut almost covered by boughs of trees. A dreadful storm, with thunder and lightning.
CORA has covered her Child on a bed of leaves and moss. Her whole appearance is wild and distracted.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O, nature! thou hast not the strength of love. My anxious spirit is untired in its march. My wearied shivering frame sinks under it.â€”And for thee, my boyâ€”when faint beneath thy lovely burthen, could I refuse to give thy slumbers that poor bed of rest? O, my child! were I assured thy father breathes no more, how quickly would I lay me down by thy dear side; but down, down forever. (Thunder and lightning.) â€”I ask thee not, unpitying storm! to abate thy rage, in mercy to poor Cora's misery; nor, while thy thunders spare his slumbers, will I disturb my sleeping cherub. Though, heaven knows, I wish to hear the voice of life, and feel that life is near me. But I will endure all, while what I have of reason holds. (Thunder and lightning.) â€”Still, still implacable, unfeeling elements!â€”Yet still dost thou sleep, my smiling innocent!â€”O, death! when wilt thou grant to this babe's mother such repose? Sure I may shield thee better from the storm. My veil mayâ€”

div.stage: While she is wrapping her mantle and her veil over him, ALONZO'S voice is heard at a great distance.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Cora!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Ha!!! (Rises.)

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Again.) Cora!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O, my heart! Sweet heaven, deceive me not! Is it not Alonzo's voice?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Nearer.) Cora!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: It isâ€”it is Alonzo!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Still nearer.) Cora! my beloved!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Alonzo!â€”Here! here! Alonzo! (Runs out.)

div.stage: The voices of Alonzo and Cora are heard as if they approached, until an exclamation of ecstacy expresses their meeting.

sp.speaker: 1st. Sol.
sp.p: I tell you we are near our out-posts, and the word we heard just now was the countersign.

sp.speaker: 2d. Sol.
sp.p: It is no such thing, comrade, we have lost our way.

sp.speaker: 1st. Sol.
sp.p: Trust to me. I will lead you safe. When you see the sun on your left hand, thenâ€”

sp.speaker: 2d. Sol.
sp.p: When we shall see the sun again, Heaven knows!

sp.speaker: 1st. Sol.
sp.p: I say the sun is on our left hand, and the campâ€” (Sees the Child.) What have we here? (Lifts the veil.)

sp.speaker: 2d. Sol.
sp.p: A child, as I'm a soldier! A lovely child! Let us carry it off.

sp.speaker: 1st. Sol.
sp.p: And what shall we do with it?â€”Let it aloneâ€”it's a heathen child.

sp.speaker: 2d. Sol.
sp.p: It sleeps so sweetly! I left one in Spain just of the same age!â€”What say you, comrade, it is abandoned here to perishâ€”I will take it and preserve it. (Takes it in his arms.)

sp.speaker: 1st. Sol.
sp.p: As you like. But make haste, or we shall not regain the campâ€”come this way! Exit.

sp.speaker: 2d. Sol.
sp.p: Poor rogue! How sound it sleeps!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Speaking without.) This way, dear Alonzo. Now I am rightâ€”thereâ€”thereâ€”under that tree. Was it possible the instinct of a mother's heart could mistake the spot! Now will you look at him as he sleeps; or shall I bring him waking, with his full blue laughing eyes to welcome you at once?â€” Yesâ€”yesâ€”stand thou thereâ€”I'll snatch him from his rosy slumber, blushing like the perfumed morn.

div.stage: She runs to the spot, and finding only the mantle and veil, which she tears from the ground, and the child gone, shrieks and stands in speechless agony.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Running to her.) My heart's beloved!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: He is gone!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Eternal God!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: He is gone!â€”My child!â€”My child!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Where did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Dashing herself on the spot.) Here!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Be calm, beloved Coraâ€”he has waked, and crept to a little distanceâ€”we shall find him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Fernando! Fernando!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Is this certainly the spot where you left him?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Is not this the veil that covered him?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Think not the worst.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: I think not. I see the blood of my child!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Cora, dear Cora! Come to my ar â€¢â€¢ .

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Give me my child or death. (Looking upward.)

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Here is a hut among the trees.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Ha! yes, yes! there lives the savage that has robbed me of my childâ€” (Beats at the door, exclaiming) Give me back my childâ€”restore to me my boy!

div.stage: Enter LAS CASAS, from the hut.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: Who calls me from my wretched solitude?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Give me back my child! (Goes into the hut and calls) Fernando!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Almighty powers! do my eyes deceive me! Las Casas!!!

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: Alonzoâ€”my beloved young friend!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: My revered instructor. (Embracing.)

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Returned.) Will you embrace this man before he restores my boy?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Alas, my friendâ€”in what a moment of misery do we meet!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Yet his look is goodness and humanity.â€” Good old man, have compassion on a wretched motherâ€”and I will be your servant while I live.â€” But do not, for pity's sakeâ€”do not say you have him notâ€”do not say you have not seen him.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p:
She is my wife. Just rescued from the Spaniard's prison, I learned she had fled to this wild forest.â€”Hearing my voice, she left the child,
and flew to meet meâ€”he was left sleeping under yonder tree.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: How!â€”did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O, you are right!â€”right!â€”Unnatural mother, that I wasâ€”I left my childâ€”I forsook my innocentâ€”but I will fly to the earth's brink, but I will find him. (Runs out.)

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Forgive me, Las Casas, I must follow her: for at night I attempt brave Rolla's escape.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: I will not leave you, Alonzo.â€”You must try to lead her to the rightâ€”that way lies your campâ€”wait not my infirm stepsâ€”I follow you, my friend.

div.head: SCENE SECOND.
div.stage: The out-post of the Spanish campâ€”the back ground wild and rocky, with a torrent falling down the precipice, over which a bridge is formed by a felled tree.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Bear him alongâ€”his story must be false.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (In chains, brought in by soldiers.) False! â€”Rolla utter falsehood!â€”I would I had thee in a desert, with thy troop around thee;â€”and I, but with my sword in this unshackled hand!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Is it to be credited that Rolla, the renowned Peruvian heroâ€”should be detected like a spy, skulking through our camp?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Skulking! Base-minded plunderer, 'tis only such as thee that know the arts of skulking and deceit: you cannot judge, cannot conceive, the motives which animate the minds of nature's children. You, by a strange frenzy driven, contend for power, for plunder and dominionâ€”we for our country, our altars, and our homes. You follow an adventurer whom you fear, and obey a power which you hateâ€”we serve a monarch whom we loveâ€”a God whom we adore. Whenever you move in anger, desolation tracks your progressâ€” wherever you pause in amity, affliction mourns your friendship.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Proud savage!â€”we come to improve your state, enlarge your thoughts, and free you from the yoke of error.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Away, away!â€”first free yourselves from passion's deadly rule, and spurn the dictates of avarice and pride. When we accept a change, it must be by virtue recommended. The rulers whom we honor, possess the people's confidence and loveâ€”the laws we reverence, are our brave fathers' legacyâ€”the faith we follow, teaches us to live in charity with all, and die with hope of bliss beyond the grave!â€”But why waste words with theeâ€”bring me to your general.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: He is here.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What, Rolla!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: To thy surprize, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: And bound too!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: So fast that thou hast nothing to fear.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The guards surprized him, passing our out-post.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Rolla, thou hearest that I am guiltless of this insult.â€”Release him. (It is done.) Nor shall a hero like Rolla depart from me unarmed. (Gives him a sword.) Learn that Spaniards know the courtesy which is due to a valiant enemy.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (Taking the sword.) And learn that Peruvians can forgive injuries. I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Only forgive?â€”I had hoped that Pizarro and Rolla might one day be friends.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I will talk to thee of friendshipâ€”as soon as the sea lies between us. May I depart?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Freely.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And shall I not again be intercepted?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: No! Let the word be given that Rolla passes freely.

div.stage: Enter DAVILLA and SOLDIERS, with the CHILD.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Here are two soldiers, who have found a Peruvian child.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What is the imp to me?â€”Bid them toss it into the sea.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Gracious heaven! it is Alonzo's child!â€” give it to me.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Ha!â€”Alonzo's child!â€”Welcome, thou pretty hostage.â€”Now Alonzo is again my prisoner!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Thou wilt not keep the infant from its mother?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Will I not?â€”What, when I shall meet Alonzo in the heat of the victorious fightâ€”thinkest thou I shall not have a check upon the valor of his heart, when he is reminded that a word of mine is this child's death?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: My vengeance has a long arrear of hate to settle with Alonzoâ€”and this pledge may help to balance the account.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Man! man!â€”Art thou a man? Couldst thou hurt that innocent?â€”By heaven! it is smiling in thy face.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Tell me, does it resemble Cora?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Pizarro! thou hast set my heart on fire. If thou dost harm that childâ€”think not his blood will sink into the barren sandâ€”no!â€”faithful to the eager hope that now trembles in this indignant heartâ€”'twill rise to the common God of nature and humanity, and cry aloud for vengeance on its accursed destroyer's head.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Be that peril mine.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (Throwing himself at his feet.) Behold me at thy feet.â€”Me, Rolla!â€”Me, the preserver of thy life!â€”Me, that have never yet bent or bowed before created man, my king excepted. In humble agony I sue to youâ€”prostrate I implore youâ€” but spare that child, and I will be your slave.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Rolla!â€”Still thou art free to goâ€”this child remains with me.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Then was this sword heaven's gift, not thine. (Seizes the child.) Who moves one step to follow me, dies upon the spot.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Pursue him instantlyâ€”but spare his life.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: With what fury he defends himself!â€”Ha! â€”he fells them to the groundâ€”and nowâ€”

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Three of your brave soldiers are already victims to your command to spare this madman's life; and if he once gains the thicketâ€”

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Spare him no longer. (Exit Almagro.) Their guns must reach himâ€”he'll yet escapeâ€” holloa! those horse!â€”the Peruvian sets themâ€” and now he turns among the rocksâ€”then is his retreat cut off.

div.stage: ROLLA crosses the tree over the cataract, pursued by the Soldiers; they fire at him; a shot strikes him.

sp.speaker: Pizâ–ª
sp.p: (Exclaims.) Now! quick! quick! Seize the child!â€”

div.stage: ROLLA tears from the rock the tree which supports the bridge, and retreats by the back ground, bearing off the Child.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: By hell! he has escaped!â€”and with the child unhurt.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Noâ€”he bears his death with him. Believe me, I saw him struck upon the side.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Dead!â€”Shot!â€”Brave man! Thou wast worthy of a nobler death!â€”I would have won thy friendship.â€”Yes, by heaven! I reverenced and admired himâ€”yetâ€”I am his murderer!â€” Away!â€”Give me a thousand men like this, and I would conquer worlds!

div.head: SCENE THIRD.
div.stage: Enter ATALIBA, followed by ALONZO, CORA, and LAS CASAS.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Oh! avoid me not, Ataliba! To whom, but to her king, is the wretched mother to address her griefs? The gods refuse to hear my prayers! Did not my Alonzo fight for you? and will not my sweet boy, if thou wilt but restore him to me, one day fight thy battles too?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Oh! my suffering love! my poor heart-broken Cora! you but wound our sovereign's feeling soul, and not relieve thy own.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Is he our sovereign, and has he not the power to give me back my child?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: When I reward desert, or can relieve my people, I feel what is the real glory of a king. When I hear them suffer, and cannot aid them, I mourn the impotence of all mortal powers.

sp.speaker: Voice behind.
sp.p: Rolla! Rolla! Rolla!

div.stage: Enter ROLLA, mortally wounded; in his right hand the bloody sword, on his left arm the child.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Gracious God!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (Sinks on one knee before Cora, and with a weak voice exclaims) Coraâ€”thy child!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: My childâ€”covered with blood!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: It is my blood. (Presenting her the child.)

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Pressing it to her breast.) My child! Rolla!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I loved thee! Thou didst me injustice! I can no moreâ€” (Sinks down.)

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Casting himself on his knee by him.) Rolla! thou diest!â€”

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: For theeâ€”and Cora!â€” (Dies.)

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Kneeling by the body.) O! who ever loved like this man? (To the Child.) Boy, thou art dearly purchased!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Starting up with an action of despair.) Las Casas! help me to believe in God!

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: His ways are dark. Have faith, pray, and be humble.

div.head: NOTES TO PIZARRO IN PERU.
div.p: THIS play is called in the original "The Spaniards in Peru; or, Rolla's Death. A Romantic Tragedy; in Five Acts."â€” The copy here presented to the public is partly translated for the New-York Theatre, and partly adapted from Mr. Sheridan's tragedy of Pizarro.
Page 9. Elvira is discovered.] In the original Elvira is attired as a man. The alteration is Mr. Sheridan's.
Same page. Power of your charms.] Here the following lines are omitted:â€”

sp.speaker: "El.
sp.p: Why do you disturb my delightful dreams?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What were you dreaming?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: That I saw you hanged.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How long will Elvira mock my love?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Your love? Who gave the bastard this honest name? Between ourselves, Valverde, when I hear you speak of love, you appear to me like a pick-pocket; who, while he bears the blessing of God in his mouth, is devising the best means of purloining your purse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What may not a handsome woman say?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: What may not a vain coxcomb do?"

div.p: Page 10. In thee I see not man.] Here the following lines are omitted:â€”

sp.speaker: "El.
sp.p: Valor captivates maiden hearts more than erudition. Pizarro fights with the sword, and you with the pen. He sheds blood, and you only ink.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And both to very little purpose.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: But with all your scribbling Nugnez Balboa had never discovered the South sea; with all the axioms of your Aristotle, Pizarro and Almagro would never have fitted out a ship. You might have remained buried in your scholastic dust; and I, perhaps, been still a nun.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Have we gained or lost, is the question?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: The uniformity of the cloister; the sleep of a dormouse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: True woman. Splendid misery is dearer to you than obscure happiness.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Do you know what we most hate? An unbidden prater, a vulgar-themed preacher."

div.p: Same page. Might have been my lot.] Here the following lines are omitted:â€”

sp.speaker: "Val.
sp.p: A holy enthusiast for what is called humanity. Nothing excites enthusiasm so quickly as words which no one understands. The imagination conceives, and brings forth a martyr.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Valverde a philosopher too?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Does it displease thee? Well, then, let us step from the clouds of philosophy to the flowering plains of love.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: They will become barren under thy footsteps. In short, my crafty friend, you must throw away the pen, seize the sword, and do something great before you pretend to the love of Elvira."

div.p: Page 11. A hero!] Here the following lines are omitted:â€”

sp.speaker: "Val.
sp.p: Great while he succeeds; but should his projects fail, the world will call him fool.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: The fate of every hero. With open mouths children behold the mounting rocket, and when it falls, laugh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Suppose it even rose to the sky, what hopes have you from it?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: To become a viceroy's wife. Pizarro will govern this rude nation; I will instruct and fashion it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Indeed! Then you little know Pizarro's subtle thirst for honor. If fortune lead him to her highest step, he will bestow his hand on one whose high birth may hide his own mean origin; whose connexions at court may be his protection. While the poor Elvira is forgotten; forgotten all that she has done and suffered.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Ha! Thenâ€”but hiss on, poisonous serpent!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: On the other sideâ€”Valverde may then be high in dignity, and Elviraâ€”his friend.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Shameless wretch!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You trample upon the flower which you might pluck, for the sake of fruit which hangs too high for you."

div.p: Four lines are substituted.
Same page. Shouts of victory.] Here the following lines are omitted:â€”

sp.speaker: "El.
sp.p: And as long as this Pizarro deserves my affection, no art shall separate me from him. When fortune turns her back upon him, Elvira will reach him her hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Slow is repentance, but she ever overtakes the thoughtless."

div.p: Page 13. Reek with human blood.] Here the following lines are omitted;â€”

sp.speaker: "El.
sp.p: Surprize? Battle? Do you take me with you, Pizarro?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: We were not speaking of a ball.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: (With feeling.) Nor did I question a dancer.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: If in my armoury you can find a sword light enough for a woman's hand, come and stand by my side in the battle.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Would you rather have me there than not?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Yes; and do you know why? The tumult of the fight will be my surety for your fidelity.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: You are wrong. The woman who is desirous of being untrue, will not be hindered by storms or earthquakes.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: I thank you for the lesson, and will write it in my memory.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: You cannot write.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (With a ferocious look.) Elvira!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Is it my fault?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: You know that I will not hear of this.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: If your nurse had broken your leg, would you be ashamed of limping?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Enough. And never again mention the subject.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: (Aside.) Achilles was only vulnerable in the heel."

div.p: Here follows the buffoon scene of the armour-bearer, which, as it has been generally condemned, and was printed contrary to the author's intention, I omit.
Page 15. Half of what I know.] Here the following lines are omitted:â€”

sp.speaker: "L. C.

sp.speaker: "El.
sp.p: You are right. Who would plant cedars in a marsh? Let us converse rationally on this subject. Fame is an irrational thing. It is mere smoke, and does not warm us. But advantageâ€”What think you, Pizarro? How if by generosity, which costs us nothing, we could purchase a dear victory?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Speak more intelligibly.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Alonzo must seal the doctrine of Las Casas:â€”whether by an heroic death, which is of little advantage to us, or by a folly, which may aid us much, depends on you.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p:
Let us catch the enthusiast with his own phantoms. That nothing, called by mortals virtue, is his idol. Go to him,
and say, "Alonzo, thou hast injured me. I forgive thee. Thou art at liberty." The boy will sink into your arms, and gratefully betray to you the throne of Quito.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Think you so? I doubt it.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: If the artifice be too difficult for you alone, I will assist you. Whom does the power of love more easily persuade to good or evil than the enthusiast? I am possessed of beauty, and of sense; and well can I accommodate myself to all the humours of your sex. You know, Pizarro, thousands obey you, the heroâ€”You me, the woman.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: I obey you!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Not another word, for time is precious. I go to Alonzo. Have I not already won his heart as a young man? How then will he feel when I appear before him as a woman, when I press his hand in mine, and rest my supplicating looks upon him; when virtue's airy precepts flow from my lips with soft persuasion?â€”Think you he can resist all this?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Your vanity amuses me.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Thank me for my good intentions, ere I repent them."

"SCENE. An open place not far from the Peruvian Camp. ATALIBA is discovered, reposing under a Tree.
Ata.
How silent and dreary is every thing around me! The sensations which succeed a victory resemble those which succeed a fever. We rejoice at the danger which is past, and have scarcely strength enough to rejoice. The smile swims in tears â€”the triumph is expressed in sighs. Conquest is dearly bought. History tells how many fell, but never tells how many are made
wretched. The arrow, which hits one heart, sometimes inflicts a hundred wounds. Oh! I would sell all my conquests for one harvest-festival.
Enter a COURTIER.
Cou.
The herald is returned without consolation.
Ata.
Is Alonzo dead?
Cou.
No, but the Spaniards have refused the ransom. "Your treasures," said the haughty spoilers, "belong to us, and in a few days we shall be your masters. Justice dwells in our strength."
Ata.
What! not yet humbled! Does this adder, then, which hisses round my throne, for ever grow again? Where is Cora?
Cou.
She fled with her child, but none knows whither. The army is alarmed and sad, for Rolla too has disappeared.
Ata.
Rolla! Impossible! He forsake me, when surrounded by distress and danger! Oh, heavens! Is there no one who wishes to obtain my dignity! I will exchange my situation for that of the meanest in my realm.
Enter ALONZO, in the Monk's habit.
Alon.
Do I behold my king again?
Ata.
Alonzo, is it you?
Alon.
Where is my wife?
Ata.
Welcome appearance!
Alon.
Where is my wife?
Ata.
How did you escape?
Alon.
By half a miracle.
Ata.
Speak!â€”Tell me all.
Alon.
Whom but Rolla could friendship urge to make so great a sacrifice? Who but Rolla could muffle himself in this mantle, and force his way even to my prison? He it was, who broke my chains to hang them on himself.
Ata.
Rolla in the power of the enemy! Alas! you wound me again.
Alon.
(Throwing off the Monk's habit.) Give me a sword, and five hundred of your boldest warriors, that I may hasten to release him.
Ata.
Shall I risk in you my last support?
Alon.
The enemy is dejected; the camp on the right side but ill defended. Pizarro, by his cruelties, has made himself detested. The soldiers murmur; let them not have time to reflect. If we obtain another victory, we may drive them into the ocean.
Ata.
Come with me. I will myself examine where it will be most proper to attack them.
Alon.
Do not thus expose yourself to danger. You are our king.
Ata.
When the children are in danger, the father should exert himself.
Alon.
Let me, then, first embrace my dearest Cora.
Ata.
(Confused.) Cora!
Alon.
Doubtless her sufferings have been great.
Ata.
They have indeed.
Alon.
In a moment I will return to you.
Ata.
Where will you seek her?
Alon.
(Alarmed.) Is she not here?
Ata.
Her terrors drove her from us.
Alon.
Whither?
Ata.
I know not. Perhaps to the mountains, where her father dwells.
Alon.
Heavens! What a chilness courses through my veins!
Cou.
She was seen running through the field of battle, and calling for Alonzo till it was dark.
Alon.
And then?
Cou.
Then she disappeared in the woods.
Alon.
The woods! where Spanish soldiers are continuallyâ€” Cora! Cora! (Going.)
Ata.
Alonzo! whither go you?
Alon.
Wherever anguish and despair may lead me. Good Inca, thou art in safety. The conquered foe dare not attempt to attack you. Oh thou, who dost protect the rights of all thy subjects, revere the rights of nature. My wife, my child, my all is lost. Release me from my duty as a leader, that I may fulfil the duties of a husband, and go in search of Cora.
Ata.
I feel thy agony. Go, but forget not Rolla.
Alon.
Cora!â€”Rolla!â€”What guardian angel will direct my steps. Exit.
Ata.
(To the Courtier.) Lend me your sword. (The Courtier presents it. Ataliba tries to raise it, but his arm sinks.) I cannot. Poor monarch! What avail reason and courage, if the limbs refuse their office. Exit."

div.stage: "An open place near the Peruvian Camp.
Enter ATALIBA with folded arms, and in deep meditation.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: The enemy is quiet. My troops are buried in sleep. The storm is over. Not a breath of air murmurs through the trees. Around me all is silence and reposeâ€”but not hereâ€” (Points to his heart.) And why not here? Am I to be pursued by the spectres of the slain? Am I to be tormented by the groans of the dying? Did I not draw the sword for God and my native land?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Whither do you lead me? Where is my infant's grave? (Espying the King.) Ha! Thouâ€”Son of the Sun, give me my child again.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Cora, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: From my son's graveâ€”deep under the earthâ€”there it is cold and damp. (Shuddering.) I shiver!

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Horrible!

div.stage: Enter ALONZO and LAS CASAS, in pursuit of CORA.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Unhappy Cora! whither does thy frenzy lead thee?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Be silent, Alonzo. Here stands the sun of the gods. The sun is his father. If he will but say a word, the grave will open, and disgorge its prey. (Embracing Ataliba's knees.) Oh, my king, speak this one powerful word! Have compassion on a mother's anguish,

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Ye gods! what means this?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: She has lost her child.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Poor mother, I cannot help you. Alas! I am but a king.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: You cannot! Who, then, can? To whom have the gods entrusted our existence? Was it not you who led the Peruvians to battle? Did not my Alonzo fight for you? Do you refuse me the only recompence for all his valorâ€”the life of a child, who will hereafter fight for you?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Destroy me, ye gods! I cannot bear this.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Springing up.) Tyrant, whom my prayers and anguish cannot move, has not blood enough yet flowed to satisfy thy rank ambition? Look! on each of thy diamonds hangs a drop of blood. Art thou not satisfied without tearing infants from their mother's breast, and casting them to beasts of prey?â€” What is thy diadem to me? What cares a mother for the throne of Quito? Hasten hither, all ye, whom this victory has robbed of children! Help me to curse this foul barbarian, and let our misery rise with his shouts of joy to heaven. Oh, if he may but feel forever the distresses of one hapless mother, his punishment will be sufficient. Sinks exhausted to the earth.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Clasping her in his armsâ€”to Ataliba.) Forgive the frenzy of a mother.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: (Wiping away a tear.) Alas! the throne supplies no compensation for this tear.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Smiling.) Alonzo, my breast is painful. Reach me the child. (Exhausted.) Alonzo, you are cruel; you see that I am dying, and will not let me once more feel the rapture of beholding my child.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Alas! This is more dreadful than her fury. Rage on, poor wretched mother! Thou no longer hast a child.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: (Falling back.) Poor wretched mother! Thou no longer hast a child.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Rolla comes.

sp.speaker: Ata. and Alon.
